results.title: What is a fish
results.creator_credit: Michael Birch and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Biology program; unit 3. Animal life”.
Illustrates the major types of fish showing the anatomy of a typical fish, behaviour patterns such as commensalism, spawning, predation and territoriality.

results.title: What is a reptile?
results.creator_credit: John Walker and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Biology program; unit 3. Animal life”.
Describes four orders of reptiles and discusses their physical characteristics, reproductive processes and their evolutionary development. Discusses reasons for the successful evolution and survival of the reptile. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: What is a mammal?
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Biology program; unit 3. Animal life”.
Demonstrates the basic structural and behavioural characteristics of mammals and describes their successful adaptation to a wide variety of ecological niches. Compares reptilian and mammalian characteristics, such as reactions to temperature, reproduction; sense organs and skull structure. Discusses the evolution of mammals, illustrates their variety and shows their distribution. Suitable for upper secondary levels.

results.title: The Ears and hearing. [Rev. ed.]
results.creator_credit: Richard Barlow, Charles L. Finance and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Biology program. Unit 4. Physiology”.
Structure and functions of the human ear and how it transmits sound waves to the brain. Discusses hearing malfunctions and records various stages of stapendectomy while the surgeon comments on the delicate procedures.

results.title: What is a bird?
results.creator_credit: Milan Herzog and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Biology program; unit 3. Animal life”.
Describes the evolutionary relations between birds and reptiles. Shows the body structures of birds and explains how their structural characteristics help them to adapt to different environments. Also illustrates various patterns of behaviour. From the Series: Biology Program Unit 3, Animal Life.
results.description:
Episode of Series “Biology program; unit 3. Animal life”.

results.title: The Eyes and seeing
results.creator_credit: Charles L. Finance and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Biology program. Unit 4. Physiology”.
Studies the eye, its component structures and their functions. Close-up studies of the parts of the eye and experiments with animals in a visual perception laboratory provide a clear distinction between the physical process and the electro-chemical process of seeing. Considers how light sources are focused on the retina activating light sensitive cells. Examines problems in determining how the brain evaluates and acts on visual stimuli.

results.title: The Jointed-legged animals: arthropods
results.creator_credit: John Walker and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Biology program; unit 3. Animal life”.
This film shows the jointed-legged animals and the structural and functional characteristics of animals in the phylum arthropoda: examples from each of the five classes, and their evolutionary development. Metamorphosis and moulting processes are illustrated using photo-micrography and time-lapse photography. The economic importance to man is discussed. Suitable for upper secondary level.

Episode of Series “Biology program; unit 3. Animal life”.

results.title: Muscle: electrical activity of contraction
results.creator_credit: Charles L. Finance and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Biology program. Unit 4. Physiology”.
Demonstrates that all muscle contractions are initiated by nerve impulses and that electrical stimuli can initiate muscle contraction.

results.creator_credit: John Walker and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Biology program; unit 3. Animal life”.
Demonstrates that the sponge represents one development of multicellularity in animals. Shows life processes and the adaptation of sponges to their environment. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Fundamentals of the Nervous System
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Biology program. Unit 4. Physiology”.
Live photography, microphotography, animated drawings and medical demonstrations illustrate the functions, diversions and specific tasks of the nervous system. Shows how it conveys information from sense organs to brain, co-ordinates information with experience and directs muscles and other organs to carry out adaptive behaviour.
